data.title: Differentiate (partially) staged changes from unstaged changes
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 1.16
- OS Version: Win 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Partially stage some changes (from the ... menu (top right) select "Stage selected ranges")
2. Open the 2 views of the same file from Source Control sidebar - first by clicking the file under "Staged Changes" which should open it with a "(Working tree)" suffix, and second by clicking the same file under "Changes" which should open it with a "(Index)" suffix. 

Both views show exact same contents. So you can't easily identify which lines were (partially) staged:

![2017-09-11_19-54-05](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2523987/30279617-5a6424bc-972b-11e7-914d-8062f0a4e93b.gif)

This is different from `git gui` which correctly shows the relevant views (stages/unstaged):

![2017-09-11_20-03-46](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2523987/30280042-620a5d52-972c-11e7-9109-fa04556271a7.gif)

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes/No

data.title: Code Terminal VIM Auto Inserts Text Value
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.16.0 (787b31c0474e6165390b5a5989c9619e3e16f953, 2017-09-06T16:19:37.192Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.12.9-300.fc26.x86_64
- Fedora 26 with KDE Plasma
- Extensions: none 

---
While commiting a project with git I noticed that when I started vim by itself or git started vim, there is text that gets pre-inserted into the document. This means I always have to enter `:q!` if I don't want to actually enter text myself. I recognize the inserted text as a password that I used the other day to log into a remote ssh session and an ftp session. I've restarted the machine more than once since I've notice this happening. This does NOT happen if I start a standard terminal session in konsole or tilix. Any help on finding where this information is being stored would be awesome.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open terminal session in vscode.
2. Start a vim instance in terminal by typing `vi` or `vim`
3. Text is somehow auto inserted into the empty vim document.

<!-- Launch with `code --disable-extensions` to check. -->
Reproduces without extensions: Yes

data.title: Syntax highlight issue
data.body:
I have the latest version of VSCode ( stable ), and I'm not sure if this is a theme issue or it's related to VSCode itself. ( I have One Dark Pro installed as theme ).

[Here is a screenshot](http://i.imgur.com/ZzzTx01.png). As you can see, the HTML code within the PHP tags is wronngly highlighted, though the tags are closed correctly.

Regards!

data.title: TreeDataProvider: custom views default to 4 lines tall

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
When you collapse an explorer view and restart/reload vscode expanding the view again will make it so short that it's usually not usable without manually expanding.

Maybe it would be useful to proportionally reduce the size of other expanded views and give the new view _1/n_ of the column height where _n_ is the number of expanded views? Then collapsing the view would redistribute its height between other views.

data.title: Multiple monitors: the VS Code window becomes invisible

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.15.1 (41abd21afdf7424c89319ee7cb0445cc6f376959, 2017-08-16T18:07:25.676Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT x64 10.0.14393
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In the display settings you should have two monitors in this order: 1, 2.
2. Set the 2nd monitor the main one.
3. "Restore" the window (make it not full-size) and place it on the 1st monitor.
4. Close VSCode.
5. Set the 1st monitor the main one.
6. Open VSCode.

In the taskbar there is an active element of VSCode, but clicking on it or Alt+Tab'ing does not make the VSCode visible. Clicking on the taskbar item prompts me with the animation that the window is to the left of the 1st monitor, beyond visibility.

The problem will not be reproduced if you perform the same actions with the 2nd monitor.

The problem will be fixed if you set back the 2nd monitor the main one and move the window to it. Of course, the problem will also be fixed if you clear the `%APPDATA%\Code` folder.

Reproduces without extensions: **Yes**

data.title: TreeDataProvider: allow programmatically changing the selection
data.body:
The default explorer view highlights the current file when the active editor changes. It would be nice to be able to match this behavior with custom tree views.

Related: https://github.com/patrys/vscode-code-outline/issues/12

data.title: Terminal: lost ability to ctrl+click on links
data.body: I am using TMUX on macOS and I was always able to click on a link in the output to open it in the editor. I think with the new canvas implementation I am no longer seeing links.

data.title: TreeDataProvider: allow specifying a command to execute when a TreeItem is highlighted

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
This would allow extensions that use tree views for navigation match the behavior of the Quick Pick panel.

Related: https://github.com/patrys/vscode-code-outline/issues/5

data.title: TreeDataProvider: allow selecting a TreeItem without affecting its collapsibleState
data.body:
Currently clicking an item will both select it and change its expanded/collapsed state. This results in very weird UX as you need to click the items to interact with them.

I have [an extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=patrys.vscode-code-outline) that provides a tree outline of the currently opened file and clicking a class name will currently select that class in the editor and at the same time expand/collapse its children in the tree view.

Related: https://github.com/patrys/vscode-code-outline/issues/24

data.title: Extension contributed colors do not show in the extensions "Contribution Tab"
data.body:
vscode-tslint is now contributing a color to the status bar.

```json
    "colors": [
      {
        "id": "tslint.error",
        "description": "Color for tslint error message in the status bar.",
        "defaults": {
          "dark": "#ffff00",
          "light": "#ffff00",
          "highContrast": "#ffff00"
        }
      },
```

However, this contribution isn't shown in the Extension overview. If the color is now show there, how can a theme author find out that such a color exists?

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/172399/30266222-fa6c86fe-96de-11e7-96ca-07631ddc2b78.png)

data.title: tsserver: TypeError: Cannot read property 'length' of undefined
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode. -->

<!-- Use Help > Report Issues to prefill these. -->
- VSCode Version: 2c385b98066eebb8e39dfd98b1fcb8cc254196b6
- OS Version: windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Edit TSX file
2. Try to define a function parameter as _something

```ts
          <Stager
            ref={(_stager)=> this.stager=_stager } // << here
            onChange={this.setTitle}

```

data.title: Integrated Terminal: Some characters not being rendered correctly
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.17.0-insider (1.17.0-insider) `2c385b98066eebb8e39dfd98b1fcb8cc254196b6`
 2017-09-11T05:06:55.533Z
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.6 (16G29)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open Integrated Terminal
2. type `echo "\xE2\x9E\x9C"` and hit enter. (Assume encoding is UTF-8)

The character `➜` (U+279C) is what I am using in command prompt.
